questions.text: A 20-Year-old lady came to OPD on the second day of menstruation with excessive intolerable cramping pain. She has had similar complaints for 2 years and is taking over-the-counter drugs for pain relief. You gave antispasmodics and sent her to get an ultrasound to differentiate between primary and secondary dysmenorrhoea. Which of the following characters refers to primary dysmenorrhoea?

options.label: D
options.text: Reassurance, NSAIDs, analgesics, antispasmodics, and OC pills are the mainstay of treatment

questions.correct_answer: D. Reassurance, NSAIDs, analgesics, antispasmodics, and OC pills are the mainstay of treatment
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reassurance, NSAIDs, analgesics, antispasmodics, and OC pills are the mainstay of treatment

Highyeild:

Primary Dysmenorrhoea is usually due to excessive myometrial contractions, ischaemia, and excessive prostaglandin production. So reassurance, analgesics, NSAIDs, antispasmodics, and OC pills are the mainstay of treatment. In rare cases, surgery - Cotte's operation or laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) is done. Secondary Dysmenorrhoea is pain due to pelvic pathology. It is congestive. Pain is present 2-3 days before menstruation and doesn't subside with onset. The most common cause is endometriosis, adenomyosis, fibroid, and polyp. Treat disease pathology.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Secondary Dysmenorrhoea is associated with pelvic pathologies like endometriosis, PID, adenomyosis, fibroid, and pelvic vein congestion. Option: B. Primary Dysmenorrhoea usually occurs within 2 years of menarche whereas Secondary Dysmenorrhoea occurs at 20 - 30 years of age, also may be pre and post-menopausal. Option: C. Associated features of primary Dysmenorrhoea are nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, and Associated features of secondary Dysmenorrhoea are dyspareunia, infertility, and menstrual disorders.

Extraedge:

Dysmenorrhoea is an indirect indicator of the ovulatory cycle. Anovulatory cycles are irregular and painless and there's often heavy bleeding. In Primary Dysmenorrhoea pain never persists beyond 48 hours.

questions.text: A 17-Year-old girl came with complaints of mood swings, irritability, bloatedness, breast pain, difficulty in concentration, abdominal cramps, and nausea around 1 week prior to menstruation. She also says that these complaints are present since her menarche. Which of the following is incorrect about the mechanisms responsible for these symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Estrogen excess or progesterone deficiency in the luteal phase

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased production of vasopressin, aldosterone, prolactin, and systemic prostaglandins

questions.correct_answer: C. Decreased production of vasopressin, aldosterone, prolactin, and systemic prostaglandins
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreased production of vasopressin, aldosterone, prolactin, and systemic prostaglandins The symptoms here point toward the diagnosis of premenstrual syndrome . The exact cause is not known and multiple biochemical abnormalities are postulated. One among them is the increased production of vasopressin, aldosterone, prolactin, and systemic prostaglandins.

Highyeild:

(PMS) has a wide variety of signs and symptoms, including mood swings, tender breasts, food cravings, fatigue, irritability, and depression. PMS is managed by: Nutritional - Balanced diet, deceased intake of sugar, caffeine, and salt. Lifestyle - Relaxation techniques, regular exercise, support groups. Medications - Progesterone, Spironolactone, Pyridoxine, SSRIs, and OCPs.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Estrogen excess or progesterone deficiency in the luteal phase may be the cause of PMS. Option: B. Pyridoxine plays a role in estrogen synthesis and also in dopamine and serotonin production. A deficiency of Pyridoxine may be a cause of PMS. Option: D. Fluctuation in opiate peptides concentration affecting endorphin levels may cause PMS.

Extraedge:

A drop in estrogen may prompt the release of norepinephrine, which leads to declining production of dopamine, acetylcholine, and serotonin in PMS. MIRENA is not used in the treatment.

questions.text: A 34-Year-old woman is hospitalized because of an enlarged, painful abdomen. An ultrasound examination is performed and the presence of ascites (fluid) in the peritoneal cavity is confirmed. A culdocentesis is being performed. Which space must the needle enter to drain the fluid?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A and B The rectouterine pouch (or pouch of Douglas) is the extension of the peritoneal cavity situated between the rectum and the posterior uterine wall of the uterus in women.

Highyeild:

The rectouterine pouch is the most dependent or lowest part of the abdominopelvic cavity when in the supine position making it a typical site of collection of the Due to its intimacy with the posterior wall of the uterus it can be examined transvaginaly or transrectaly by digital palpation. Fluids collected there may also be drained through the vagina or rectum without entering the abdominopelvic cavity transabdominally.

Extraedge:

The uterovesical pouch is formed by the peritoneum over the uterus, and bladder, continued over the intestinal surface and fundus of the uterus onto its vesical surface. Its more anterior location dictates that when the body is in a supine position, fluid that accumulates there will immediately travel down to deeper parts of the peritoneal cavity like the rectouterine pouch.

questions.text: An 18-Year-old female presents with an acute abdomen. Her UPT is positive. You wish to perform culdocentesis to ascertain the presence of blood in the pelvis from a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. How do you insert the needle to perform culdocentesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Through the perineal body into the vesicouterine space

options.label: B
options.text: Through the posterior fornix of the vagina into the rectouterine pouch

options.label: C
options.text: Through the anterior fornix into the vesicouterine space

options.label: D
options.text: Through the perineal membrane into the rectouterine pouch

questions.correct_answer: B. Through the posterior fornix of the vagina into the rectouterine pouch
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Through the posterior fornix of the vagina into the rectouterine pouch It is very likely that the ectopic pregnancy ruptured into the rectouterine pouch, also known as the pouch of Douglas. The most direct route to the rectouterine pouch is through the posterior vaginal fornix.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : It is unlikely that the pregnancy would have occurred in the vesicouterine space because the transfer of ova from the ovary to the fimbriae occurs on the posterior side of the broad ligament. Therefore, it would not be advisable to attempt initially to insert a needle into the vesicouterine space. Options C and D : These are distractor options.

Extraedge:

The uterovesical pouch is formed by the peritoneum over the uterus and bladder, continued over the intestinal surface and fundus of the uterus onto its vesical surface. Its more anterior location dictates that when the body is in a supine position, fluid that accumulates there will immediately travel down to deeper parts of the peritoneal cavity like the rectouterine pouch.

questions.text: A 34-Year-old nulliparous diabetic woman complains of loss of urine with coughing and sneezing for 5 months. The patient is sexually active and uses a barrier method of contraception. Her cycles are regular and her LMP is 2 weeks ago. 5 years ago she was treated for chlamydia. Family history of DM present. She smokes 10 cigarettes per day. She weighs 53kgs, height is 160 cms. On per vaginal examination, an irregularly enlarged anteverted and anteflexed uterus is seen. Which of the following will reveal the cause of the patient's urinary symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

USG abd and pelvis Diagnosis: Stress Urinary Incontinence due to fibroids (enlarged anteverted and anteflexed uterus puts pressure on the uterus).

Highyeild:

Stress Urinary Incontinence is the most common incontinence in young women. It is the result of rises in bladder pressure due to intra-abdominal pressure increases. Gold standard surgery: Colposuspension Bursch . The treatment of choice is Trans Obturator Tape.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Bladder CA is suspected, as smoking increases the risk in this patient. But the symptoms would be hematuria, increased urinary frequency, or urge incontinence, not stress incontinence. Option B: Although the gravid uterus may cause stress urinary incontinence due to increased intra-abdominal pressures. But on P/V the uterus is irregularly enlarged. And her LMP is just 2 weeks ago. Option D: NAAT is used to diagnose chlamydial infection of the cervix or urethra. It causes mucopurulent discharge and dysuria and not stress incontinence.

Extraedge:

Q Tip Test is the clinical test used to diagnose Stress Urinary Incontinence. Submucosal fibroids have been associated with infertility .

questions.text: A lady approaches a physician for contraceptive advice. On examination, there were two symmetrical ulcers on the vulva, which were well-defined with a firm base. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Syphilis Painless well-defined ulcers with a firm base should raise suspicion of the Chancre is the primary lesion of primary syphilis.

Highyeild:

It is most commonly found on the labium majus , labium minus, fourchette, clitoris, urethral orifice, or cervix. In 10% of the cases, more than one primary lesion is present. The first manifestation is a small papule which breaks to form an ulcer. The ulcer is firm, and painless with raised edges and granulomatous base. In fact, any sort of discrete relatively painless ulceration on the vulva may be a primary syphilitic lesion. Inguinal glands enlarge when the primary is on the vulva or lower vagina. Lymph nodes are hard, painless , and do not suppurate.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: Herpes presents multiple painful vesicles on an erythematous base. Option A: Chancre presents as a painful lesion. Lymph nodes are also painful. Option D: Malignancy presents as an ill-defined growth, usually hard and painless.

Extraedge:

Genital Ulcerative Disorder Granuloma Inguinale Chancroid Syphilis LGV K. Granulomatis H. Ducreyi T. Pallidum C. Trachomatis Bleeds on touch Bleeds on touch Does not bleed Does not bleed Pseudobubo + Painless LN Painful LN Painless LN Painless LN

questions.text: A 25-Year-old female with a history of multiple contacts presenting with growth on the vulva, the probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Condyloma accuminata The history of sexual exposure and growth on the vulva is consistent with condyloma accuminata.

Highyeild:

Condyloma accuminata: It is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Warts are seen on the vulval area. Warts are common in the regions affected most directly by coitus i.e. posterior fourchette and lateral areas of the These verrucous growths may coalesce to form large cauliflower growths. Condyloma is associated with vulval, vaginal, and cervical cancers. Diagnosis is by colposcopy which shows raised patches of aceto-white epithelium with a speckled appearance. Management: Young women with condylomas may be observed for 6 months , especially if it develops during pregnancy. Treatment options include: – Podophyllin. Cannot be used during pregnancy – Imiquimod Trichloroacetic acid : Can be applied in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy to avoid cesarean section with large lesions. Electrocoagulation/Cryotherapy/Laser therapy : Can be done in pregnancy but before 32 WEEKS to avoid post-treatment necrosis which may last as long as 4–6 weeks.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: Verruca plana: – Hands and face are the most common site, warts are not seen in the genital area. – It is usually seen in children. – Sometimes, it can also occur in young women, but the face is the most common site involved. Option C: Verruca vulgaris: the site of warts is different, usually affected areas are exposed parts of the body, hand, feets, arms, legs, face, and scalp. Option D : Condyloma lata: is the growth seen on genitalia in secondary syphilis.

questions.text: Based on the Image, what is your diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Genital herpes The image shows clusters of vesicles on erythematous bases. It may show painful lymphadenopathy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - Condyloma lata is also called genital warts, which are characterized by painless, mucosal, and warty erosions which are flat, velvety, moist, and broad base in nature. Option C - Condyloma accuminata consists of exophytic broad excrescences that ulcerate. Option D - Chancroid is an ulcer caused by either syphilis or H. Ducreyi. Typically, an erythematous papule develops at the site of inoculation, which quickly becomes a pustule and subsequently develops into an extremely painful ulcer with soft irregular margins, often referred to as a "soft chancre."

questions.text: Based on the Image, what is your diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Condyloma accuminata Also called venereal warts, these are caused by HPV, which is a small DNA double-ended virus.

Highyeild:

These warts spread diffusely over the whole of the vulval area. The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. They affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vagina. Viral tests: DNA test, hybridization, PCR staining. CD4 count shows immune functioning. Colposcopic appearance: as patches of raised projection of acetowhite epithelium with a speckled appearance. Treatment: Young women with condyloma lata may be observed for 6 months. Local application of podophyllin. This treatment is, however, contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy and in vaginal and cervical lesions because of severe inflammatory The larger lesions are best removed by diathermy loop or laser ablation. The surgical excision of a localized growth is another alternative. The husband should be treated simultaneously or protected from infection by advising the use of condoms. Vulval and vaginal warts during pregnancy mandate cesarean section to avoid papilloma laryngitis in the neonate.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - The image will show clusters of vesicles on an erythematous base. It may show painful lymphadenopathy. Option C - Exophytic broad excrescences that ulcerate. Option D - Is an ulcer caused by either syphilis or H. Ducreyi.

Extraedge:

Other treatments: Interferon local ointment or cream or intralesional injection, Inosiplex is an immunomodulator used as an adjunct to conventional therapy, Imiquimod cream.

questions.text: Based on the Image, what is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Condyloma lata These are highly contagious exophytic broad excrescences that ulcerate. These are commonly seen on the vulva, perianal area, and upper thighs. After 2–6 weeks, it passes into the phase of latent syphilis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - The image will show clusters of vesicles on an erythematous base. It may show painful lymphadenopathy. Option C - Condyloma accuminata consists of exophytic broad excrescences that ulcerate. Option D - Is an ulcer caused by either Syphilis or H. Ducreyi. Typically, an erythematous papule develops at the site of inoculation, which quickly becomes a pustule and subsequently develops into an extremely painful ulcer with soft irregular margins, often referred to as a "soft chancre."

questions.text: A 22-Year-old female patient presents to you in PHC with a painful ulcer on the vulva with tender inguinal lymph nodes. How will you manage her?

options.label: A
options.text: Treat her with a white kit. No need to treat her husband.

options.label: B
options.text: Treat her with a yellow kit and a gray kit for her husband.

options.label: C
options.text: Treat her and her husband with a white kit.

options.label: D
options.text: Treat her with a white kit but a gray kit for her husband.

questions.correct_answer: C. Treat her and her husband with a white kit.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Treat her and her husband with a white kit. White Kit is used for non-herpetic genital ulcer disease.

Highyeild:

Partner management when asymptomatic is not required for herpes, candida, and Gardnerella vaginalis. Kit 1 Gray - Urethral discharge, cervicitis. Kit 2 Green - Vaginal discharge Kit 3 White - Non-Herpetic Genital Ulcers Kit 4 Blue - Non-Herpetic Genital Ulcers, and allergic to penicillin. Kit 5 Red - Herpetic Genital Ulcers Kit 6 Yellow - Lower Abdominal Pain Kit 7 Black - Scrotal swelling

questions.text: A 22-Year-old female patient presents to you in PHC with a painful ulcer on the vulva with tender inguinal lymph nodes. She has a history of allergic reaction to penicillin. How will you manage her?

options.label: A
options.text: Treat her with a white kit. No need to treat her husband.

options.label: B
options.text: Treat her with the yellow kit and grey kit for her husband

options.label: C
options.text: Treat her and her husband with a white kit

options.label: D
options.text: Treat her with a blue kit.

questions.correct_answer: D. Treat her with a blue kit.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Treat her with a blue kit. Treat her with a blue kit as she is allergic to penicillin.

Highyeild:

Partner management when asymptomatic is not required for herpes, candida, and Gardnerella vaginalis. Kit 1 Gray - Urethral discharge, cervicitis. Kit 2 Green - Vaginal discharge Kit 3 White - Non-Herpetic Genital Ulcers Kit 4 Blue - Non-Herpetic Genital Ulcers, and allergic to penicillin. Kit 5 Red - Herpetic Genital Ulcers Kit 6 Yellow - Lower Abdominal Pain Kit 7 Black - Scrotal swelling

questions.text: Based on the image, which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The husband need not be treated.

options.label: B
options.text: If present in the vulval area and vagina it is an indication of cesarean section.

options.label: C
options.text: If detected in the first trimester of pregnancy, immediate treatment with podophyllin is necessary.

questions.correct_answer: C. If detected in the first trimester of pregnancy, immediate treatment with podophyllin is necessary.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

If detected in the first trimester of pregnancy, immediate treatment with podophyllin is necessary. If detected in the first trimester of pregnancy, immediate treatment with podophyllin is necessary is a false statement. Options A, B, and D are true.

Highyeild:

Also called venereal warts, these are caused by HPV, which is a small DNA double-ended virus . These warts spread diffusely over the whole of the vulval area. The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. They affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vagina. Viral tests: DNA test, hybridization, PCR staining. CD4 count shows immune functioning. Colposcopic appearance: as patches of raised projection of acetowhite epithelium with a speckled appearance. Treatment: Young women with condyloma lata may be observed for 6 months , especially when it develops during pregnancy. Local application of podophyllin . This treatment is, however, contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy because the drug is absorbed into the circulation and is cytotoxic causing abortion and peripheral neuropathy. This treatment is also contraindicated in vaginal and cervical lesions because of severe inflammatory reactions provoked at these sites. The larger lesions are best removed by diathermy loop or laser ablation. The surgical excision of a localized growth is another alternative.

Extraedge:

The husband should be treated simultaneously or protected from infection by advising the use of condoms. Vulval and vaginal warts during pregnancy mandate cesarean section to avoid papilloma laryngitis in the neonate Other treatments: interferon local ointment or cream or intralesional injection. Inosiplex is an immunomodulator used as an adjunct to conventional therapy, imiquimod cream.

questions.text: The minimum criteria to diagnose PID includes all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fever

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C, and D are true.

Extraedge:

Most common PID due to IUCD: Actinomyces Most common PID in virgin females: Genital TB Most common route of spread of PID: Ascending infection except genital TB which is spread by a hematogenous route. Prognostic scoring for conception in a case of PID can be done using Boer Miesel Score

questions.text: During laparoscopy, the preferred site for obtaining cultures in a patient with acute PID is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fallopian tube For the identification of organisms in PID the materials are collected from the following available sources: Discharge from the urethra or Bartholin’s gland. Cervical canal. Collected pus from the fallopian tubes during laparoscopy or laparotomy. The material collected is subjected to Gram’s stain and culture (aerobic/anaerobic). The findings of gram-negative diplococci is very much suggestive of gonococcal infection.

questions.text: A 15-week pregnant woman has dysuria and vaginal discharge. On inspection, the cervix appears congested and swollen with the presence of mucopurulent discharge in the endocervical canal. What is the drug of choice to treat her condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Penicillin Gonorrhea causes purulent/flow of seed kind of discharge.

Highyeild:

Chlamydia causes mucopurulent discharge. In non-pregnant females – DOC for Chlamydia is Azithromycin. Treatment of chlamydia infection during pregnancy: Preferred choice Azithromycin (1 g) as a single dose Amoxicillin or (500 mg) orally 3 times a day × 7 days

questions.text: The risk factors of acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) are the following except:

options.label: A
options.text: Menstruating teenagers who have multiple sex partners.

options.label: C
options.text: Women with monogamous partners who have had a vasectomy.

questions.correct_answer: C. Women with monogamous partners who have had a vasectomy.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Women with monogamous partners who have had a vasectomy. Women with a monogamous partner who had a vasectomy are a protective factor for PID and not a risk factor.

Highyeild:

Risk factors of PID include: Menstruating teenagers. Multiple sexual partners. Absence of contraceptive pill use. Previous history of acute PID. IUD users. Area with a high prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases. Protective factors of PID include: Sterilization operation prevents PID by blockage of the tubes. Apart from barrier contraceptives progesterone-containing pills produce a thick plug of mucus in the cervical canal and prevent the ascent of organisms.

questions.text: A 22-Year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician with lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She's sexually active and uses OCP. LMP 15 days ago. Her temperature is 39°C. O/E shows dry mucous membranes, soft and symmetrical abdomen, and diffuse tenderness over the lower quadrant. P/S shows purulent discharge from the cervical os. The uterus is normal size and tender. Adnexa tender but no palpable mass is noted. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Admit the patient and wait for culture results.

options.label: B
options.text: Inpatient treatment with cefotetan and doxycycline.

options.label: C
options.text: OPD treatment with metronidazole and ampicillin.

options.label: D
options.text: OPD treatment with oral amoxicillin and clavulanic acid

questions.correct_answer: B. Inpatient treatment with cefotetan and doxycycline.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inpatient treatment with cefotetan and doxycycline. This patient has PID with nausea and vomiting. Hospitalization and parenteral antibiotics are recommended for high fever, failure to respond to oral antibiotics, inability to take oral medication due to nausea and vomiting, pregnancy, and for patients at risk of non-compliance.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Antibiotic therapy for PID should never be delayed until culture results are obtained Option C : In non-hospitalized patients, i.m cefoxitin is used with oral probenecid and oral doxycycline, or i.m ceftriaxone and oral doxycycline are administered. Option D : Amoxicillin plus clavulanic acid does not provide proper coverage for PID.

questions.text: A 20-Year-OLD G2P2 with LMP 5 days ago presented to the emergency room complaining of a 24-hour history of increasing pelvic pain. She has chills and a fever. Her only surgery was a laparoscopy performed last year for an ectopic pregnancy. She reports regular menses and denies dysmenorrhea. She is currently sexually active. She has a new sexual partner and had sexual intercourse with him just prior to her last menstrual period. WBC is 18,000. The temperature is 38.8°C (102°F). On physical examination, her abdomen is diffusely tender in the lower quadrants with rebound and voluntary guarding. Bowel sounds are present but diminished. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pelvic inflammatory disease Ovarian torsion, appendicitis, and acute salpingitis are all commonly associated with fever, abdominal pain, and elevated white blood cell count. Ruptured ovarian cysts present with acute abdominal pain without fever.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Ovarian torsion is usually associated with an adnexal mass. Option D : Pain from ruptured ovarian cysts may occur at any time throughout the menstrual cycle but is Often present around the time of ovulation. Option C : Although appendicitis is the differential diagnosis in any woman presenting with abdominal pain and fever, it is unlikely as the patient has no nausea, vomiting, or anorexia.

questions.text: A patient with H/O PID presents to you with a fever and RUQ pain. On laparoscopy, the following image is seen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fitz–Hugh Curtis syndrome The image shows a band of fibrous tissue stretching from the right fallopian tube to the undersurface of the liver.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Tietze syndrome is a rare, inflammatory disorder characterized by chest pain and swelling of the cartilage of one or more of the upper ribs (costochondral junction), specifically where the ribs attach to the breastbone (sternum). The onset of pain may be gradual or sudden and may spread to affect the arms and/or shoulder Option B : Reiter’s Syndrome (now known as Reactive Arthritis) develops in response to an infection and is characterized by a triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and nonspecific urethritis Option C : Scalded Skin Syndrome, SSSS, or Ritter's Disease, is a skin infection caused by Staphylococcus Aureus.

questions.text: A 22-Year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, and purulent discharge from the cervix. The following organism is seen on microscopy from the smear. How will you manage this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Yellow kit for her and Gray kit for her husband.

options.label: C
options.text: Yellow kit for her and her husband.

questions.correct_answer: B. Yellow kit for her and Gray kit for her husband.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Yellow kit for her and Gray kit for her husband. Image shows intracellular Gram-negative diplococci indicating Neisseria gonorrhea.

Highyeild:

' Partner management when asymptomatic is not required for herpes, candida, and Gardnerella vaginalis. Kit 1 Gray - Urethral discharge, cervicitis. Kit 2 Green - Vaginal discharge Kit 3 White - Non-Herpetic Genital Ulcers Kit 4 Blue - Non-Herpetic Genital Ulcers, and allergic to penicillin. Kit 5 Red - Herpetic Genital Ulcers Kit 6 Yellow - Lower Abdominal Pain Kit 7 Black - Scrotal swelling

questions.text: A 34-Year-old woman with IUD in situ for 5 years develops a fever, abdominal pain, abnormal bleeding, and discharge. Sulfur granules can be recognized. The following image is obtained from the sample. How will you treat her?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Penicillin The diagnosis is PID caused by Actinomyces . Actinomyces is an anaerobic gram-positive filamentous, non-sporing bacterial infection often associated with The infection is treated with 250,000 units/kg daily of penicillin IV in four doses for 2–6 weeks. Thereafter, oral 100 mg/kg daily in divided doses is administered for 3 – 12 months. Other antibiotics are tetracycline, erythromycin, clindamycin, and chloramphenicol.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C, and D - are used to treat gonorrhea and chlamydial infection.

Extraedge:

Most common PID in virgin females: Genital TB Most common route of spread of PID: Ascending infection except genital TB which is spread by a hematogenous route. Prognostic scoring for conception in a case of PID can be done using Boer Miesel Score

questions.text: A 28-Year-old adolescent female undergoes laparoscopy for an acute abdomen. Erythematous fallopian tubes are noted and a diagnosis of PID is made. Cultures of purulent drainage would most likely reveal which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multiple organisms Multiple organisms are most likely encountered in acute salpingitis .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B & C N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis are the two most common organisms involved. Other vaginal organisms, such as anaerobic bacteria, are also usually involved in the mix. Option D: Peptostreptococcus are anaerobic, Gram-negative bacteria that are a natural part of human flora along the gastrointestinal (GI) and urinary tracts. They are not involved in salpingitis.

questions.text: The following procedure is indicated in all of the following women, except:

options.label: A
options.text: 23-year old with an abnormal HSG showing u/l spasm of cornu

options.label: D
options.text: 22-year-old presenting with a history of PID

questions.correct_answer: D. 22-year-old presenting with a history of PID
questions.explanation:
Solution:

22-year-old presenting with a history of PID Laparoscopy demonstrates the external condition of the fallopian tubes as well as the patency. It is, however, an invasive procedure and requires hospitalization. Hence not first line investigation for a 22 year old presenting with history of PID.

Highyeild:

The given image is of diagnostic laparoscopy with chromopertubation. Indications for laparoscopy in infertility: HSG showing abnormal findings. Prior to planning tuboplasty. Prior to IUI. Prior to induction of ovulation. Removal of hydrosalpinx prior to IVF. PCOD to puncture the cysts to improve the pregnancy rate of assisted reproduction and avoid hyperstimulation syndrome. Suspected cases of endometriosis.

questions.text: A patient with discharge per vagina was evaluated and on endocervical biopsy, Chlamydia was found. Treatment to be given in this case is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Azithromycin and contact tracing

Highyeild:

Management of Chlamydia: Uncomplicated chlamydia can be treated with Tetracycline (500 mg 4 times daily), Doxycycline (1000 mg twice daily), Erythromycin (500 mg 4 times daily), Fluoroquinolone -ofloxacin 300 mg twice daily, or Azithromycin - single dose 1 g. The advantages of Azithromycin are: Single dose regimen – 1 g stat dose (It is as effective as 7 days of doxycycline treatment). Better patient compliance. Fewer gastrointestinal side effects. Disadvantage: High cost of Azithromycin. Contact tracing: Patients with asymptomatic infection and their sex partners form a major burden of chlamydial infection so, contact tracing should always be done (wherever possible).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C, and D are false.

questions.text: Salpingitis/Endosalpingitis is best confirmed by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hysteroscopy and laparoscopy Laparoscopy is considered the “gold standard”. While it is the most reliable aid to support the clinical diagnosis, it may not be feasible to do in all cases. It is reserved only in those cases in which differential diagnosis includes salpingitis, appendicitis, or ectopic pregnancy. Non-responding pelvic mass needs laparoscopic clarification.

Highyeild:

Fallopian tube culture can be obtained laparoscopically and recently the hysteroscopic approach has been introduced. The specimen is obtained during hysteroscopy with a cytobrush. Since laparoscopy is an invasive procedure for the diagnosis of salpingitis/PID, the diagnosis should first be made clinically.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C, and D are false.

questions.text: Regarding asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy, all are correct except:

options.label: C
options.text: It should be treated with the appropriate antimicrobial agent

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of progression to a symptomatic state, if left untreated is rare

questions.correct_answer: D. The risk of progression to a symptomatic state, if left untreated is rare
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The risk of progression to a symptomatic state, if left untreated is rare Asymptomatic bacteriuria is when the bacterial count of the same species is over 105/mL . Overall incidence during pregnancy ranges between 2-10% If left untreated, 25% of the women with asymptomatic bacteriuria develop acute pyelonephritis, hence it should be promptly treated.
